item.title: [Geophysics] A silent and periodic earthquake trigger
item.creator: Brent Grocholski
item.description: Large earthquakes that hit places such as Japan seem to be preceded by subtle and silent deformation. Uchida et al. show that these “slow-slip events” are quasi-periodic in – [Read More]
item.subject: Geophysics

item.title: [History of Science] Babylonian astronomers tracked Jupiter
item.creator: Keith T. Smith
item.description: Ancient Babylonian astronomers developed many important concepts that are still in use, including the division of the sky into 360 degrees. They could also predict the positions of – [Read More]
item.subject: History of Science

item.title: [Superconductivity] Going to extremes to find superconductivity
item.creator: Jelena Stajic
item.description: Quantum phase transitions (QPTs) occur at zero temperature when parameters such as magnetic field or pressure are varied. In heavy fermion compounds, superconductivity often accompanies – [Read More]
item.subject: Superconductivity

item.title: [Cystic Fibrosis] Airway infections put to an acid test
item.creator: Paula A. Kiberstis
item.description: Most people with cystic fibrosis suffer from chronic respiratory infections. The mechanistic link between this symptom and the genetic cause of the disease (mutations that compromise – [Read More]
item.subject: Cystic Fibrosis

item.title: [Immunology] All T cells can remember
item.creator: Kristen L. Mueller
item.description: One of the hallmarks of adaptive immunity is that T and B lymphocytes “remember” previous infections, protecting the host from subsequent infections. When T cells respond to a pathogen, the – [Read More]
item.subject: Immunology

item.title: [Sex Chromosome] Replacing the Y chromosome
item.creator: Beverly A. Purnell
item.description: The mammalian Y chromosome encodes a specialized set of genes that are essential for male viability and fertility. In particular, the sex-determining region Y (SRY) protein is necessary – [Read More]
item.subject: Sex Chromosome

item.title: [Lunar Formation] Rehomogenizing the Earth-Moon system
item.creator: Brent Grocholski
item.description: A giant impact formed the Moon, and lunar rocks provide insight into that process. Young et al. found that rocks on Earth and the Moon have identical oxygen isotopes. This – [Read More]
item.subject: Lunar Formation

item.title: [Metabolism] Antisense now makes sense
item.creator: Megan Frisk
item.description: Mipomersen is a U.S. Food and Drug Administration-approved antisense oligonucleotide that lowers low-density lipoprotein (LDL) in patients with high cholesterol by targeting apolipoprotein – [Read More]
item.subject: Metabolism

item.title: [Developmental Biology] A MEK threshold in the placenta
item.creator: Nancy R. Gough
item.description: The kinases MEK1 and MEK2 have the same substrates, but mice lacking Mek1 die as embryos because of placental defects, whereas mice lacking Mek2 are viable. Aoidi – [Read More]
item.subject: Developmental Biology

item.title: [Melanoma Initiation] Visualizing the beginnings of melanoma
item.creator: Beverly A. Purnell
item.description: In cancer biology, a tumor begins from a single cell within a group of precancerous cells that share genetic mutations. Kaufman et al. used a zebrafish melanoma model to visualize – [Read More]
item.subject: Melanoma Initiation

item.title: [Polymers] Doubling down on polymerization
item.creator: Phil Szuromi
item.description: In biology, structural polymers such as cytoskeletal fibers assemble from covalently polymerized monomers through weaker supramolecular interactions such as hydrogen bonds. Yu et – [Read More]
item.subject: Polymers

item.title: [Stress Response] How cells keep going in the face of adversity
item.creator: Stella M. Hurtley
item.description: When cells experience stresses that affect their ability to process newly synthesized proteins, they turn down their rates of translation to help them survive the stress. They also – [Read More]
item.subject: Stress Response

item.title: [Structural Biology] Structure of a key spliceosomal complex
item.creator: Valda Vinson
item.description: In eukaryotes, when DNA is transcribed into RNA, the primary transcript has protein-coding sequences interrupted by noncoding sequences called introns. Introns are removed by a complex – [Read More]
item.subject: Structural Biology

item.title: [Surface Science] Nanoclusters just by adding CO
item.creator: Phil Szuromi
item.description: The most closely packed surfaces of transition metals are usually stable under vacuum, but during catalytic reactions, energetic changes that result from adsorbing molecules could change – [Read More]

item.title: [Oceanography] Searching sediment for climate signals
item.creator: Brent Grocholski
item.description: Sediments on the ocean floor may provide clues about the interplay between ice ages and mid-ocean ridge magma production. Lund et al. present well-dated and detailed sediment – [Read More]
item.subject: Oceanography

item.title: [Biochemistry] A special way to make T
item.creator: Guy Riddihough
item.description: The genomes of all cell-based life consist of DNA. Blocking DNA synthesis is thus lethal, and if targeted selectively, its inhibition can provide cancer and antibiotic treatments. For – [Read More]
item.subject: Biochemistry

item.title: [Conservation] Patterns of biodiversity change
item.creator: Julia Fahrenkamp-Uppenbrink
item.description: Invasive species and climate change are altering the composition of ecosystems worldwide. In a Perspective, Magurran considers the effects of these changes, which come in addition to – [Read More]
item.subject: Conservation

item.title: [Evolution] Genetics of bird mating systems
item.creator: Julia Fahrenkamp-Uppenbrink
item.description: Elaborate courtship behaviors are no rarity in birds, but some species even have differently colored types of males and females—or morphs—with different reproductive strategies. In – [Read More]
item.subject: Evolution

item.title: [Molecular Evolution] Environmental changes bridge evolutionary valleys
item.creator: Philip Yeagle
item.description: Molecular evolution of individual protein molecules can be described in a “landscape” of possible amino acid sequences containing peaks and valleys. Peaks characterize the beneficial nat – [Read More]
